text: Harold Boyd Woodruff (July 22, 1917 â€“ January 19, 2017) was an American soil microbiologist. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences. He was known for the discovery of actinomycin, and the development of the industrial production by fermentation of many natural products. This included cyanocobalamin (a synthetic form of Vitamin B12), the avermectins, and other important antibiotics. Woodruff died on January 19, 2017, at the age of 99 at his home in Watchung, New Jersey.Roberts, Sam. "H. Boyd Woodruff, Microbiologist Who Paved Way for Antibiotics, Dies at 99", The New York Times, February 3, 2017. Accessed February 4, 2017. ==References== Category:1917 births Category:2017 deaths Category:Scientists from New Jersey
title: H. Boyd Woodruff
